title: Configure NFS volumes (Helm)
content:
If a container stops and is then restarted, all changes made inside the container get lost. To save information such as configuration files or databases, the system must store the information in a persistent volume provided by a Network File System (NFS). To install OPTIC Management Toolkit (OMT) and then deploy the suite on OMT, you need to export these NFS volumes to store OMT and suite data. 

NFS volumes required for the suite

In the following table, the NFS volume label column lists the volumes that you will use to deploy the ESM helm chart. You will need to manually configure your NFS server. 

<base directory> in the table below refers to the parent NFS server directory of the NFS volumes. For example, if the NFS base directory is /var/vols/itom and the volume is logging-volume, then the NFS export path is /var/vols/itom/logging-volume.

You should have already configured the NFS volumes for OMT during the OMT installation by following the instructions in the OMT documentation.

For information about NFS storage sizing and management, see  Manage persistent storage for the suite.

Supported NFS settings

The storage technology that provides NFS implementation must support the Kubernetes persistent mount option of ReadWriteMany. That means you can mount a storage volume to multiple nodes in read/write mode in parallel. In an on-premises environment, you can use one of the following storage types:

  • Self-hosted NFS storage
  • Managed NFS storage

The following table describes the supported NFS settings for each storage type.

NFS settings Self-hosted NFS storage Managed NFS storage
  • rw
  • sync
  • The following permission configurations: 
    chmod -R 755 <path to the exported volume>
chown <SYSTEM_USER_ID>:<SYSTEM_GROUP_ID> <path to the exported volume>
  • The following line in the /etc/exports file: 
    <path to the shared folder on the NFS server> (rw,sync,anonuid=<SYSTEM_USER_ID>,anongid=<SYSTEM_GROUP_ID>,root_squash)
 Supported Supported when the NFS storage is using root_squash 
  • rw
  • sync
  • The following permission configuration: 
    chmod -R 755 <path to the exported volume>
chown <SYSTEM_USER_ID>:<SYSTEM_GROUP_ID> <path to the exported volume>
  • The following line in the /etc/exports file: 
    <path to the shared folder on the NFS server> (rw,sync,no_root_squash)
 Not supported Supported when the NFS storage is using no_root_squash
  • The UID and GID of the exported NFS folders are configured in the install.properties file through the SYSTEM_USER_ID and SYSTEM_GROUP_ID parameters, both of which have a default value of 1999. You can use 1999 or a custom value between 100000 and 2000000000 (for example, 100001 as the UID and 100002 as the GID). As an example,  the command lines below use 1999.  
  • You can use one or more NFS servers for OMT and the suite.
  • If you run antivirus software, backup software, or any other software that scans the file system on the machine that hosts the NFS server, don't use the software to monitor the Smart Analytics NFS directory (for example: <base directory>/smartanalytics-volume), because this will have a significant impact on the performance of IDOL indexing and IDOL search. 

Configure NFS shares if using self-hosted NFS storage

  1. Log on to the NFS server as root or a sudo user. 
  2. Run the rpm -qa|grep rpcbind command to make sure that the rpcbind package is installed on the host.
    If the package isn't already installed, run the following command to install it: 
    yum install rpcbind

  3. Run the following command to install the NFS server:

    yum install -y nfs-utils

  4. Run the following commands to enable the rpcbind and nfs-server services:

    systemctl enable rpcbind
systemctl start rpcbind
systemctl enable nfs-server
systemctl start nfs-server

  5. Copy the OMT installation package to a temporary directory on the NFS server

  6. Run the following command to unzip the OMT installation package: 
    unzip <OMT_Embedded_K8s_2x.x-xxx.zip>

  7. Navigate to the OMT_Embedded_k8s_2x.x-xxx/cdf/scripts directory, and then run the following command for each shared volume:

    ./setupNFS.sh <shared volume> true <SYSTEM_USER_ID> <SYSTEM_GROUP_ID>
    For example: 
    ./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/logging-volume true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/config-volume true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/data-volume true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-0 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-1 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-2 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-3 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-4 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-5 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-0 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-1 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-2 true 1999 1999

./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-4 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-5 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawarc-con-0 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawarc-con-1 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawarc-con-a-0 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawarc-con-a-1 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawmeta-con-0 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawmeta-con-1 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawmeta-con-a-0 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawmeta-con-a-1 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/rabbitmq-infra-rabbitmq-0 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/rabbitmq-infra-rabbitmq-1 true 1999 1999
./setupNFS.sh /var/vols/itom/itsma/rabbitmq-infra-rabbitmq-2 true 1999 1999

    The values of and configured here must be the same as the values for the global.securityContext.user and global.securityContext.fsGroup parameters when you create your custom my-values.yaml file for the suite deployment in the later step. That is, if you use the values in this example (100001 for and 200001 for ) instead of the default value 1999, you must also change the values for global.securityContext.user and global.securityContext.fsGroup to 100001 and 200001 in your custom my-values.yaml file.

  8. Check the permission of each folder must be set to 755. If it is not, use the following command to change the permissions: 
    chmod -R 755 <path to shared folder>

    For example:

chmod -R 755  /var/vols/itom/itsma/rabbitmq-infra-rabbitmq-2
  9. Set the ownership of the volumes. Run the following command to change the ownership for volumes: 
    chown -R <UID>:<GID> /var/vols/itom/itsma.
  10. Check the exported NFS volumes: 
    showmount -e

Limit access to the exported NFS folders

Role Location Privileges required
System administrator NFS server Root or sudo

We strongly recommend that you limit access to the exported NFS directories to a specific host or hosts in a subnet. All control plane nodes and worker nodes must have the access to the exported NFS directories. To do this, follow these steps:

  1. On the NFS server, open the /etc/exports file, and then add the following line for each exported directory to which you want to limit access: 
    <path to shared directory> <host IP1>(rw,sync,anonuid=<SYSTEM_USER_ID>,anongid=<SYSTEM_GROUP_ID>,root_squash)
<path to shared directory> <host IP2>(rw,sync,anonuid=<SYSTEM_USER_ID>,anongid=<SYSTEM_GROUP_ID>,root_squash)

    For example, you add the following line: 
    /var/vols/itom/itsma/logging-volume 192.0.0.2(rw,sync,anonuid=1999,anongid=1999,root_squash)
/var/vols/itom/itsma/logging-volume 192.0.0.3(rw,sync,anonuid=1999,anongid=1999,root_squash)

    You can also allow hosts in a specific subnet to access the exported NFS directories. To do this, add the following line for each exported directory to which you want to limit access:
      
    <shared directory1> <IP of subnet host>(rw,sync,anonuid=<SYSTEM_USER_ID>,anongid=<SYSTEM_GROUP_ID>,root_squash)
<shared directory2>; <IP of subnet host>(rw,sync,anonuid=<SYSTEM_USER_ID>,anongid=<SYSTEM_GROUP_ID>,root_squash)
    For example, you add the following line: 
    /var/vols/itom/itsma/logging-volume 192.0.2.0/16(rw,sync,anonuid=1999,anongid=1999,root_squash)
/var/vols/itom/itsma/config-volume 192.0.2.0/16(rw,sync,anonuid=1999,anongid=1999,root_squash)
  2. Save the /etc/exports file, and then run the following command: exportfs -r

Each time you add a new node to the cluster, make sure the IPv4 address or hostname of this node is in the allowable address list to grant the node access to the shares.

Configure NFS shares if using managed NFS storage

Perform the following steps on a control plane node, according to whether the NFS storage is using root_squash or no_root_squash.

 Before performing the following steps, you must mount your managed NFS storage server to the control plane node. For example: 
mkdir /mountPoint
sudo mount -t nfs <NFS Server IP>:/ /mountPoint/

If using root_squash

  1. Log in to the control plane node.
  2. Perform steps 7 through 9 described in the Configure NFS shares for self-hosted NFS storage section.

If using no_root_squash

  1. Log in to the control plane node.
  2. Navigate to the mount point directory, cd /mountPoint/
  3. Create a directory for each NFS volume.  
    mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/logging-volume
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/config-volume
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/data-volume
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/rabbitmq-infra-rabbitmq-0
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/rabbitmq-infra-rabbitmq-1
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/rabbitmq-infra-rabbitmq-2
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawarc-con-0
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawarc-con-1
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawarc-con-a-0
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawarc-con-a-1
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-0
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-1
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-2
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-3
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-4
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-5
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-0
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-1
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-2
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-3
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-4
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-saw-con-a-5
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawmeta-con-0
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawmeta-con-1
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawmeta-con-a-0
mkdir -p /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawmeta-con-a-1
  4. Change the permission for each directory that you created. If you are using the same base directory for all NFS volumes, you can simply run the chmod -R 755 command. For example: 
    chmod -R 755 /var/vols/itom

    If you aren't using the same base directory, repeat the chmod command for each NFS directory. For example:

    chmod -R 755 /var/vols/itom/itsma/logging-volume
...
chmod -R 755 /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawmeta-con-a-1
  5. Add a group and user: groupadd -g <SYSTEM_GROUP_ID> itsma useradd -g <SYSTEM_GROUP_ID> -u <SYSTEM_USER_ID> itsma For example:

    If you are using the same base directory for all NFS volumes, run the chmod -R g+w <base directory> command. For example:

    groupadd -g 1999 itsma 
useradd -g 1999 -u 1999 itsma
  6. Change the owner of each directory that you created by using the chown -R : command. If you're using the same base directory for all NFS volumes, simply run the chown -R : command. For example: 
    chown -R 1999:1999 /var/vols/itom/itsma
    Alternatively, change the owner for each NFS directory. For example: 
    chown -R 1999:1999 /var/vols/itom/itsma/config-volume
...
chown -R 1999:1999 /var/vols/itom/itsma/itsma-smarta-sawmeta-con-a-1
  7. Run the chmod -R g+s command. If you are using the same base directory for all NFS volumes, run the chmod -R g+s command. For example: 
    chmod -R g+s /var/vols/itom/itsma
    Alternatively, repeat the chmod -R g+s command for each NFS directory instead.
  8. Run the following command. If you are using the same base directory for all NFS volumes, run the chmod -R g+w command. For example: 
    chmod -R g+w /var/vols/itom/itsma
    Alternatively, repeat the chmod -R g+w command for each NFS directory instead.
